item.title: Stellar Blade Gets A Cheerful Holiday Update This Week With New Minigame
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/stellar-blade-gets-a-cheerful-holiday-update-this-week-with-new-minigame/1100-6528497/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Shift Up has announced that Stellar Blade will get a free holiday-themed update tomorrow, December 17.

In this update, Eve gets a Santa Dress and Adam gets the ironic "I'm No Santa" costume complete with a full white beard. Eve can complement her holiday look by also equipping the Santa Girl hairstyle and the Snow Crystal Glasses, Wreath Earrings, and Sleigh Ear Cuffs. Eve's drone also receives the Rudolph Pack that attaches a new look to it, complete with a red nose and horns.

A new minigame has been added as well. It looks like players just have to shoot at a target wrapped in a wreath to win prizes, although it wasn't stated what those prizes were. At camps, players can choose the seasonal "Dawn (Winter)" and "Take Me Away" background music tracks. Last but not least, the update adds a Christmas tree in The Last Gulp, the bar where Xion's citizens gather.

In the settings, players can also toggle seasonal and DLC content on/off whenever they want, which includes the holiday and Nier: Automata content.

Stellar Blade is currently available for PS5, and on sale for $50 as part of PlayStation's holiday sale. Shift Up is aiming to release it on PC next year. This isn't the only game to get a holiday update, either--just last week, Astro Bot got the Winter Wonderland update.

George Yang on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Elden Ring Is Rapidly Catching Up To Dark Souls' Sales
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/elden-ring-is-rapidly-catching-up-to-dark-souls-sales/1100-6528496/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

From Software launched Elden Ring in February 2022, and the game quickly caught on among players. It was a massive hit from the start--so much so that the sales of Elden Ring have almost caught up with From's previous franchise, Dark Souls, in just under three years.

Bandai Namco has announced that as of September 2024, Elden Ring has sold 28.6 million copies worldwide. The Shadow of the Erdtree DLC expansion surely helped raise those numbers in 2024. Before Elden Ring's 2022 release, the Dark Souls games sold 27 million copies combined. This led some observers to suggest that Elden Ring had already surpassed Dark Souls' all-time numbers.

Fun Fact: The entire Dark Souls series had sold 27 million units combined prior to Elden Ring's release.
Now Elden Ring alone has surpassed that total. https://t.co/Y8yLNzdhfZ

— Daniel Ahmad (@ZhugeEX) December 15, 2024

However, that was a premature assessment. The Dark Souls games now have more than 37 million copies to their name, which means that Elden Ring still has a ways to go before it catches up. But given that Elden Ring was heavily discounted for Black Friday, it may have closed some of the distance between the two franchises. Bandai Namco hasn't shared those updated numbers yet.

Surprisingly, From Software doesn't seem to be in a hurry to make Elden Ring 2. In the meantime, the recently announced co-op game, Elden Right Nightreign, is expected to debut in 2025. While Nightreign won't have cross-play, players on PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S will be able to sign up for a test starting early next year.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Former Cyberpunk Devs' The Blood Of Dawnwalker Will Get Full Reveal In Time For Full Moon
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/former-cyberpunk-devs-the-blood-of-dawnwalker-will-get-full-reveal-in-time-for-full-moon/1100-6528494/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Studio Rebel Wolves has announced that it will host a reveal livestream for its debut game, The Blood of Dawnwalker, on January 13 at 1 PM PT / 4 PM ET. Coincidentally, that date will also be the next time a full moon will appear.

In a tweet, Rebel Wolves said, "Witness the premiere of a CGI trailer serving as the game's opening, learn about the game's pillars and main concepts, have a tiny first glimpse into its gameplay... and much more." The studio already revealed the game's official title and logo, as well as the fact that it will be published by Bandai Namco.

On January 13th, under the next full moon…
Gather round at /DawnwalkerGame Twitch channel to hear about Vale Sangora – its turbulent history, natural landscapes, and secret inhabitants.
Witness the premiere of a CGI trailer serving as the game's opening, learn about the game's… pic.twitter.com/aLLkfRvqfM

— Dawnwalker (@DawnwalkerGame) December 15, 2024

The Blood of Dawnwalker is a dark fantasy RPG that's being built in Unreal Engine 5. The studio was founded by former CD Projekt Red Director Konrad Tomaszkiewicz in February 2022. Other people working on The Blood of Dawnwalker include design director Daniel Sadowski, narrative director Jakub Szamalek, animation director Tamara Zawada, and art director Bartłomiej Gaweł.

In November 2022, NetEase acquired a minority stake in Rebel Wolves, and the studio retained full creative control and ownership of its IP.

CD Projekt Red is currently working on The Witcher 4, which got a reveal trailer at The Game Awards 2024. This time around, Ciri is the main character, but previous protagonist Geralt will still make an appearance.

George Yang on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Alan Wake 2 Update Lets You Disable The PS5 Pro's Most Defining Feature
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/alan-wake-2-update-lets-you-disable-the-ps5-pros-most-defining-feature/1100-6528492/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Alan Wake 2 has been one of a handful of games that hasn't gotten off to the best start on Sony's new PlayStation 5 Pro. Image quality issues, persistent performance wobbles, and challenges with the console's exclusive AI-upscaling technology, PSSR have all been noted. A new update for the survival-horror game aims to fix most of these issues, some of which boil down to disabling PSSR entirely.

Alan Wake 2 is the first game to allow players to toggle PSSR on or off, with the game falling back to its previous implementation of AMD's FSR upscaling when disabled. In most instances, PSSR has been an improvement over FSR (which uses linear scaling as opposed to AI-enchanced upscaling), but Alan Wake 2 has been an outlier. In its analysis of the game on PS5 Pro, Digital Foundry observed issues with image quality that FSR handled better. It did, however, note that PSSR was overall a better solution.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Alan Wake 2: Lake House DLC - Control 2 Teaser

It's clear then that developer Remedy is giving players the option to decide for themselves, letting them omit one of the biggest features of the PS5 Pro entirely if they choose. Included in the patch is a new 40fps mode, too, which balances the image enhancements found in the PS5 Pro Quality mode and the fluidity of the Performance mode if you have a display that supports 120Hz.

Further adjustments to image settings have also been made to the Performance mode to stabilize the frame rate, while other tweaks the to game's ray-traced reflections should reduce their overall noisy presentation. The update also includes some smaller changes to DLC content, as well as minor fixes across all platforms. It's available to download now, with the full patch notes listed below.

Improvements and additions

  • [PS5 Pro] Added a new “Balanced” graphics mode. This mode requires compatible displays that can achieve a 120Hz refresh rate. The Balanced mode combines PS5 Pro Quality mode settings including raytracing with Performance mode resolution. This mode targets 40fps.
  • [PS5 Pro] Slightly adjusted visual settings of the Performance mode to achieve a more consistent framerate.
  • [PS5 Pro] Quality and Balanced mode: Adjusted Raytracing settings to achieve a less noisy image.
  • [PS5 Pro] Added an option to toggle PSSR (PlayStation Spectral Super Resolution) On/Off.

Fixes

  • [The Lake House] Fixed manuscript collectables that showed the wrong page in Saga’s Mind Place.
  • [The Lake House] Fixed “Welcome to the Lake House” video collectable missing audio.
  • Minor fixes and optimizations.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
